title: Portland Cocktail Week inspires special drinks around town: The Cocktail Hour
text:
Bars around town are breaking out specials to showcase their work as hundreds of bartenders flow into town for Portland Cocktail Week. Here's a sampling:
Teardrop Cocktail Lounge
The drink: Americano???
Go out and get it: 1015 N.W. Everett St., 503-445-8109, teardroplounge.com
Make it at home: Combine 1 1/2 ounce Roseline Cold Brew Coffee, 1 ounce Cocchi Vermouth de Torino, 1 ounce Campari and a pinch of salt in a Collins or pint glass over crushed ice. Swizzle until a frost forms on the outside of the glass. Top with additional ice if needed. Garnish with an orange peel.
What they say: "A cool aperitif pick-me-up served on crushed ice. ... We added the question marks in the drink because it is essentially the Americano coffee drink (espresso and water) and Americano the cocktail (Campari, sweet vermouth and soda) combined into one. (Daniel Shoemaker, owner)
B&T Oyster Bar
The drink: Tina Louise
Go out and get it: 3113 S.E. Division St., btoysterbar.com
Make it at Home: Shake 3/4 ounce mezcal, 3/4 ounce tequila, 1/2 ounce lemon juice, 1/2 ounce amaretto, 1/4 ounce ginger syrup, 2-5 drops tincture and 1 dash Angostura bitters with ice. Strain into cocktail glass. Garnish with mint tip.
What they say: "I'm in love with Ginger from 'Gillagan's Island.' This drink is the embodiment of her — spicy, smoky, and fruity!" (Christian Rouillier, bar manager)
Ataula
The drink: La Diada
Go out and get it: 1818 N.W. 23rd Place Portland, 503-894-8904, ataulapdx.com
Make it at home: Shake 1 1/2 ounce Clear Creek apple brandy, 3/4 ounce Yzaguirre Rojo Vermut, 1/2 ounce lemon juice, 3 dashes Angostura bitters and 3 dashes cinnamon tincture with ice. Strain into a Collin glass, top with sparkling apple cider.
What they say: "I chose Clear Creek's apple brandy for its light body, but rich, fresh flavor. Not only do the people of Oregon love it, but it's a highly regarded distillery around the country that bartenders have been mixing with for years. The Spanish vermut brings depth, the cinnamon tincture spice, and the local cider carbonated on top gives it a crisp autumn feel similar to a toddy without the heat." (Angel Teta, bar manager)
Nostrana
The drink: Rooster Island
Go out and get it: 1401 SE Morrison St., 503-234-2427, nostrana.com
Make it at home: Combine 1/2 ounce each Bacardi Heritage rum, Olmeca Altos Plata tequila, Gordon's dry gin, Fris vodka, Combier orange liqueur, limoncello, Cappellano Borolo chinato and lemon juice plus 1/4 ounce honey syrup (3 parts honey, 1 part water) in a Perlini carbonation canister. Add ice and shake for 12 seconds. Add CO2 to canister slowly. Pour over fresh once in a tall glass. Add a lemon twist for garnish.
What they say: "The Rooster Island is Nostrana's version of a Long Island Iced Tea. Instead of a cola being added, I have replaced its flavor profile with the Cappellano and carbonated it with the Perlini system. The house limoncello gives it some brightness. This cocktail definitely has a big punch and is not for the inexperienced imbibers. The Rooster Bar strikes again." (Peter Carpenter, bar manager)
Little Bird
The drink: The Revolución
Go out and get it: 215 S.E. Sixth Ave.; 503-688-5952; littlebirdbistro.com
Make it at home: Shake 1 ounce Fidencio mezcal joven,1 ounce Plantation 5-Year Rum, 1/2 ounce Angostura amaro, 1/2 ounce simple syrup and 3/4 ounce lime juice with ice. Double-strain into a chilled coupe.
What they say: "The blend of the smokey and vegetal mezcal blends softly with the sweetness of the aged rum. The cinnamon spice of the Angostura amaro rounds out this complex daiquiri into a bright yet warm cocktail that makes you want to dangerously drink more!" (JP Peterson, bar manager)
Note: Little Bird will feature a "secret" menu of three specials during Cocktail Week, the Revolucion being one of them. Ask the bartender for the menu.
Olympia Provisions Southeast
The drink: Nuts & Thistles
Go out and get it: 107 S.E. Washington St., 503-954-3663, olympiaprovisions.com
Make it at home: Shake 1 ounce Luxardo amaretto, 1/2 ounce Gosling's Black Seal rum, 1 ounce Cardamaro, 1 ounce lemon juice and 2 dashes Fee Brothers Walnut Bitters with ice for about 15 seconds. Strain into a Collins glass and add fresh ice. Garnish with orange zest
What they say: "This is like an amaretto sour on crack — refreshing and balanced with dark, rich fall flavors." (Emily Salko, assistant general manager)
Imperial
The drink: Paper Chase
Go out and get it: 410 S.W. Broadway, 503-228-7222, imperialpdx.com
Make it at home: Dry shake 1 ounce vodka, 1/2 ounce apricot eau de vie, 1/2 ounce lemon juice, 3/4 ounce orgeat, 1 dash cardamom bitters and 1 egg white. Shake again with ice, strain into a cocktail glass, garnish with a strip of Angostura bitters and a cardamom pod.
What they say: "Apricot, almond and cardomom work great together and combine a feeling of an Indian summer and the beginning of autumn while the egg white provides a great mouthfeel for a balanced, well-rounded drink." (Tony Gurdian, lead barman)
Departure
The drink: Bonsai
Go out and get it: 525 S.W. Morrison St. (15th floor), 503-802-5370, departureportland.com
Make it at home: Shake 1 1/2 ounce Bombay Sapphire East gin, 3/4 ounce lemon juice and simple syrup with ice, strain into a chilled flute spritzed with Clear Creek Doug Fir Eau de Vie. Top with 1 1/2 ounce prosecco. Garnish with rosemary sprig.
What they say: "Departure being a modern Asian restaurant, we wanted to use the Bombay Sapphire East because of its focus on eastern botanicals like lemongrass and black pepper. We also wanted something light that would be a perfect way to get things going before dinner. We chose fresh lemon juice, dry prosecco, and Doug Fir Eau de Vie because they all complement the gin in a unique way. We also added a touch of simple syrup to balance things out." (Josue Moreno)
Aviary
The drink: Curried Coconut Brandy Milk Punch
Go out and get it: 1733 N.E. Alberta St., 503-287-2400, aviarypdx.com
Make it at home: Shake 1 1/2 ounce coconut milk, 1 1/2 ounce brandy, 1/2 ounce amaretto, 1 teaspoon of powdered sugar, 2 dashes of curry tincture (made by steeping curry in high proof liquor for several days) and 1 dash of cardamom bitters with ice. Strain over fresh ice and dust with fresh nutmeg.
What they say: "You really can't get any more comfy than an old school milk punch. We're kicking that up a notch with that old familiar coconut/curry/cardamom combo and just a hint of almond, to remind us all to get back to the basics and enjoy some classy simple cocktails." (Kaysie Condron, bar manager)
Note: During Cocktail Week, Aviary will have a special cocktail list in addition to their regular cocktail list from pre-Prohibition cocktail books.
Fogo de Chão
The drink: Caramelized Pineapple Old Fashioned
Go out and get it: 930 S.W. Sixth Ave., 503-241-0900, fogodechao.com
Make it at Home: Place 4 pineapple cubes on a cookie sheet. Sprinkle with 2 tablespoons Sugar in the Raw. Brown with a kitchen torch or under the broiler in the oven until golden brown. Add 3 of the cubes to cocktail shaker, along with 1/8 orange slice, maraschino cherry and 1/2 ounce sugar. Muddle well. Add 1 1/2 ounce Bulleit rye whiskey. Shake 20 seconds with ice. Skewer a cherry and last pineapple cubee and place into rocks glass with ice. Strain drink into glass.
What they say: "Fresh caramelized pineapple is flawlessly muddled with orange and decadent Luxardo gourmet maraschino cherries to enhance the caramel notes of Bulleit's Rye Whiskey. The new cocktail pairs well with the fire-roasted meats offered at Fogo de Chão. (Jim Cannon, leader of food and beverage innovation)
Levant
The drink: The Levantine Fizz
Go out and get it: 2448 E Burnside St., 503-954-2322, levantpdx.com
Make it at home: Vigorously dry shake 1 ounce green Chartreuse, 1/4 ounce Benedictine, 3/4 ounce New Deal Vodka, 1 ounce lemon juice, 3 ounces cream, 3/4 ounce egg white and 3/4 ounce mint syrup (2 parts sugar, 1 part mint tea). Add ice and shake hard again. Double-strain into a Collins glass and slowly add 2 ounces seltzer water. Garnish with mint and calendula petals.
What they say: "The array of flavors at Levant for brunch is so fantastic that I was inspired to create an ultimate accompaniment. The broad spectrum of herbal ingredients in our house Levantine Fizz is balanced with a mint and cream backbone and the perfect citrus undertone to create something truly extraordinary. It will set the tone for a very satisfying day." (John Paul Longenecker, bar manager)
Smallwares
The drink: "Grape Drink"
Go out and get it: 4605 N.W. Fremont St., 971-229-0995, smallwarespdx.com
Make it at home: Muddle 1/2 teaspoon sugar, 1 ounce red seedless grapes and 1 shiso leaf. Add 1 ounce pisco, 1 ounce Vermouth Perucchi, 1/2 ounce Benedictine, 1/2 ounce lemon juice and 2 dashes rhubarb bitters. Shake with ice and strain over fresh ice in a Collins glass. Top with soda water. Garnish with a shiso leaf and two dashes sansho powder.
What they say: "The kitchen suggested we use grapes for the cocktail since they are season and they had some extra lying around. I wanted to use other liquors that were made from grapes also and I found a good balance with the pisco and Vermouth Perucchi. The shiso and sansho add a nice perfumy note that complements the grapes." (Travis Ferguson, bar manager)
Urban Farmer
The drink: Manzanita
Go out and get it: 525 S.W. Morrison St., urbanfarmerportland.com
Make it at Home: Shake 1 1/2 ounce reposado tequila, 1/2 ounce mezcal, 1 ounce lime juice, 1/2 ounce cinnamon syrup and 1 ounce apple shrub with ice. Double-strain into a martini glass. garnish with a thin slice of fresh apple dusted with cinnamon.
What they say: "I wanted to create a cocktail that was appropriate for the season. Something delightful, crisp and reminded me of fall/winter season. I really love apples, enjoy making shrub syrups, so combining the two in this creation was my direction as the key ingredients. Tequila is a great spirit and definitely one of my favorites to build drinks with so I grabbed the bottle of Cazadores reposado — another favorite — off the shelf as the base spirit and added a touch of mezcal to give this drink some depth. Add a little cinnamon syrup, fresh lime juice to bring it all together and voila!" (Josue Moreno, manager)
Bluehour
The drink: The Farrah Fawcett
Go out and get it: 250 N.W. 13th Ave., bluehouronline.com
Make it at Home: Shake 2 ounces fresh green apple juice, 1 ounce brandy, 1 ounce Becherovka and 1/2 ounce lime juice with ice. Strain into a footed Collins glass and top with Becherovka whipped cream and dust with nutmeg.
What they say: "My general rule is healthy drinking, but with fall comes a little rule breaking. Fresh juiced local orchard apples, brandy, becherovka, lime juice, topped with becherovka whip cream and nutmeg. Mix in the whip cream and it's like a boozy milkshake." (Giselle Minshull bar manager)
Ringside Grill
The Drink: 9 Swords
Go out and get it: 14021 N.E. Glisan St., ringsidegrill.com
Make it at home: Stir 3/4 ounce Laird's Bonded Apple Brandy, 3/4 ounce Smith & Cross Rum, 1/2 ounce Gran Classico, 1/4 ounce St. Elizabeth Allspice Dram and small pinch of salt with ice for 15 seconds. Strain into a small cocktail glass.
What they say: "Some winter spice notes from the St. Elizabeth complement the brown sugar and molasses from the rum rounded out by the apple and vanilla. A simple combination of bold ingredients that is more than the sum of its parts." (Brian Quigley, lead bartender)
Raven & Rose
The drink: Coconut Lassi
Go out and get it: 1331 S.W. Broadway, 503-222-7673, ravenandrosepdx.com
Make it at home: Place 1 1/2 ounces Bombay Sapphire gin, 3 ounces coconut milk, 1 ounce lemongrass-cardamom syrup, 1/2 ounce egg white, 3/4 ounce cucumber water in a blender with crushed ice and blend for 10 seconds. Pour into tulip glass or Collins glass. Garnish with rose petals and rose water mist.
Note: This cocktail earned Raven & Rose bartender Estanislano "Tanis" Orona the title of Portland's Most Inspired Bartender by GQ Magazine.
-- Colin Powers
